fields.title: Le Père Goriot
fields.author: Honoré de Balzac
fields.book_description: Le Père Goriot is an 1835 novel by French novelist and playwright Honoré de Balzac, included in the Scènes de la vie privée section of his novel sequence La Comédie humaine.

fields.title: The Colour of Magic
fields.author: Terry Pratchett
fields.book_description: The Colour of Magic is a 1983 fantasy comedy novel by Terry Pratchett, and is the first book of the Discworld series. The first printing of the British edition consisted of only 506 copies. Pratchett has described it as "an attempt to do for the classical fantasy universe what Blazing Saddles did for Westerns.

fields.title: Mort
fields.author: Terry Pratchett
fields.book_description: Mort is a fantasy novel by British writer Terry Pratchett. Published in 1987, it is the fourth Discworld novel and the first to focus on the character Death, who only appeared as a side character in the previous novels.

fields.title: The Shining
fields.author: Stephen King
fields.book_description: The Shining is a horror novel by American author Stephen King. Published in 1977, it is King's third published novel and first hardback bestseller: the success of the book firmly established King as a preeminent author in the horror genre.

fields.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
fields.author: Oscar Wilde
fields.book_description: The Picture of Dorian Gray is a Gothic and philosophical novel by Oscar Wilde, first published complete in the July 1890 issue of Lippincott's Monthly Magazine. Fearing the story was indecent, prior to publication the magazine's editor deleted roughly five hundred words without Wilde's knowledge.

fields.title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
fields.author: Yuval Noah Harari
fields.book_description: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind is a book by Yuval Noah Harari, first published in Hebrew in Israel in 2011 based on a series of lectures Harari taught at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, and in English in 2014.

fields.title: Homo Deus
fields.author: Yuval Noah Harari
fields.book_description: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow is a book written by Israeli author Yuval Noah Harari, professor at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

fields.title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
fields.author: Yuval Noah Harari
fields.book_description: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century is a book written by bestseller Israeli author Yuval Noah Harari and published in August 2018 by Spiegel & Grau in the US and by Jonathan Cape in the UK.

fields.title: Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup
fields.author: John Carreyrou
fields.book_description: Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup is a nonfiction book by journalist John Carreyrou, released May 21, 2018. It covers the rise and fall of Theranos, the multibillion-dollar biotech startup headed by Elizabeth Holmes.

fields.title: The Man Who Solved the Market
fields.author: Gregory Zuckerman
fields.book_description: Bestselling author and veteran Wall Street Journal reporter Zuckerman answers the question investors have been asking for decades: How did Jim Simons do it? Simons is the greatest money maker in modern financial history.

fields.title: How Judges Think
fields.author: Richard Posner
fields.book_description: A distinguished and experienced appellate court judge, Posner offers in this new book a unique and, to orthodox legal thinkers, a startling perspective on how judges and justices decide cases.

fields.title: Competing Against Luck: The Story of Innovation and Customer Choice
fields.author: Clayton M. Christensen, Taddy Hall, Karen Dillon, David S. Duncan
fields.book_description: The foremost authority on innovation and growth presents a path-breaking book every company needs to transform innovation from a game of chance to one in which they develop products and services customers not only want to buy, but are willing to pay premium prices for.How do companies know how to grow?

fields.title: Good Economics for Hard Times
fields.author: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo
fields.book_description: Good Economics for Hard Times: Better Answers to Our Biggest Problems is a non-fiction book by Abhijit V. Banerjee and Esther Duflo, both professors of Economics at MIT. It was published on November 12, 2019 by PublicAffairs, Juggernaut Books and Allen Lane.

fields.title: Le Petit Prince
fields.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
fields.book_description: The Little Prince is a novella by French aristocrat, writer, and aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. It was first published in English and French in the US by Reynal & Hitchcock in April 1943, and posthumously in France following the liberation of France as Saint-Exupéry's works had been banned by the Vichy Regime.

fields.title: Eugénie Grandet
fields.author: Honoré de Balzac
fields.book_description: Eugénie Grandet is a novel first published in 1833[1] by French author Honoré de Balzac. While he was writing it he conceived his ambitious project, The Human Comedy, and almost immediately prepared a second edition, revising the names of some of the characters so that Eugénie Grandet then fitted into the section: Scenes from provincial life (Scènes de la vie de province) in the Comédie.

fields.title: Du contrat social
fields.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
fields.book_description: The Social Contract, originally published as On the Social Contract; or, Principles of Political Rights (French: Du contrat social; ou Principes du droit politique) by Jean-Jacques Rousseau, is a 1762 book in which Rousseau theorized about the best way to establish a political community in the face of the problems of commercial society, which he had already identified in his Discourse on Inequality (1755).

fields.title: L'Assommoir
fields.author: Émile Zola
fields.book_description: L'Assommoir [lasɔmwaʁ] (1877) is the seventh novel in Émile Zola's twenty-volume series Les Rougon-Macquart. Usually considered one of Zola's masterpieces, the novel—a study of alcoholism and poverty in the working-class districts of Paris—was a huge commercial success and helped establish Zola's fame and reputation throughout France and the world.

fields.title: Camille
fields.author: Pierre Lemaitre
fields.book_description: Camille is a crime novel written by French novelist Pierre Lemaitre. The novel, though originally published in French in 2012, came to be translated to English by Frank Wynne in 2015. It won the CWA International Dagger award 2015 amidst much international acclaim.

fields.title: Tarantula
fields.author: Thierry Jonquet
fields.book_description: Mygale (Tarantula) is a thriller crime novel by Thierry Jonquet first published in France by Editions Gallimard in 1984, and then published in the US in 2003 by City Lights.

fields.title: Les Misérables
fields.author: Victor Hugo
fields.book_description: Les Misérables is a French historical novel by Victor Hugo, first published in 1862, that is considered one of the greatest novels of the 19th century. In the English-speaking world, the novel is usually referred to by its original French title.

fields.title: L'Étranger
fields.author: Albert Camus
fields.book_description: L'Étranger is a 1942 novel by French author Albert Camus. Its theme and outlook are often cited as examples of Camus's philosophy, absurdism coupled with that of existentialism, though Camus personally rejected the latter label.

fields.title: If Only It Were True
fields.author: Marc Levy
fields.book_description: If Only It Were True is the first novel by the French author Marc Levy. It was released in 1999 by Éditions Robert Laffont, and was translated into English the following year. The novel has been adapted into an array of motion pictures, including the 2005 American film Just Like Heaven.

fields.title: Journey to the End of the Night
fields.author: Louis-Ferdinand Céline
fields.book_description: Journey to the End of the Night is the first novel by Louis-Ferdinand Céline. This semi-autobiographical work follows the life of Ferdinand Bardamu. Journey to the End of the Night is a semi-autobiographical novel.

fields.title: Zazie in the Metro
fields.author: Raymond Queneau
fields.book_description: Zazie in the Metro or Zazie is a French novel written in 1959 by Raymond Queneau, and his first major success.

fields.title: The Three Musketeers
fields.author: Alexandre Dumas
fields.book_description: The Three Musketeers is a historical adventure novel written in 1844 by French author Alexandre Dumas. It is in the swashbuckler genre, which has heroic, chivalrous swordsmen who fight for justice.

fields.title: The Horla
fields.author: Guy de Maupassant
fields.book_description: The Horla is an 1887 short horror story written in the style of a journal by the French writer Guy de Maupassant, after an initial, much shorter version published in the newspaper Gil Blas, October 26, 1886. American horror writer H. P.

fields.title: Bel Ami
fields.author: Guy de Maupassant
fields.book_description: Bel-Ami is the second novel by French author Guy de Maupassant, published in 1885; an English translation titled Bel Ami, or, The History of a Scoundrel: A Novel first appeared in 1903.

fields.title: Les Malheurs de Sophie
fields.author: Countess of Ségur
fields.book_description: Sophie's Misfortunes is a children's book written by the Countess of Ségur. The book was published in 1858 by the publisher Hachette. The illustrations were by Horace Castelli, a French artist. This is the first book of a trilogy; its sequels are Good Little Girls and The Holidays.

fields.title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room
fields.author: Gaston Leroux
fields.book_description: The Mystery of the Yellow Room is a mystery novel written by French author Gaston Leroux. One of the first locked-room mystery novels, it was first published serially in France in the periodical L'Illustration from September 1907 to November 1907, then in its own right in 1908.

fields.title: Le Livre des Baltimore
fields.author: Joel Dicker
fields.book_description: NOVEMBER 24, 2004The day of the tragedy. The end of a brotherhood.The Baltimore Boys. The Goldman Gang. That was what they called Marcus Goldman and his cousins Woody and Hillel.

fields.title: The Truth About the Harry Quebert Affair
fields.author: Joel Dicker
fields.book_description: The Truth About the Harry Quebert Affair is a novel by Swiss author Joël Dicker. It was published in the United States on 27 May 2014, by Penguin Books.

fields.title: Zadig
fields.author: Voltaire
fields.book_description: Zadig; or, The Book of Fate is a novella and work of philosophical fiction by the Enlightenment writer Voltaire. It tells the story of Zadig, a philosopher in ancient Babylonia.

fields.title: The Last Day of a Condemned Man
fields.author: Victor Hugo
fields.book_description: The Last Day of a Condemned Man is a short novel by Victor Hugo first published in 1829. The novel recounts the thoughts of a man condemned to die. Victor Hugo wrote this novel to express his feelings that the death penalty should be abolished.

fields.title: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame
fields.author: Victor Hugo
fields.book_description: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame is a French Gothic novel by Victor Hugo, published in 1831. The novel has been described as a key text in French literature and has been adapted for film over a dozen times.

fields.title: Froth on the Daydream
fields.author: Boris Vian
fields.book_description: Froth on the Daydream is a 1947 novel by French author Boris Vian. Though told as a linear narrative, the novel employs surrealism and contains multiple plot lines, including the love stories of two couples, talking mice, and a man who ages years in a week.

fields.title: Le Grand Meaulnes
fields.author: Alain-Fournier
fields.book_description: Le Grand Meaulnes is the only novel by French author Alain-Fournier, who was killed in the first month of World War I. The novel, published in 1913, a year before the author's death, is somewhat biographical – especially the name of the heroine Yvonne, for whom he had a doomed infatuation in Paris.

fields.title: Capital in the Twenty-First Century
fields.author: Alain-Fournier
fields.book_description: Capital in the Twenty-First Century is a 2013 book by French economist Thomas Piketty. It focuses on wealth and income inequality in Europe and the United States since the 18th century. It was initially published in French in August 2013; an English translation by Arthur Goldhammer followed in April

fields.title: The Order of Things: An Archaeology of the Human Sciences
fields.author: Michel Foucault
fields.book_description: The Order of Things: An Archaeology of the Human Sciences by Michel Foucault deals with the origins of the sciences of biology, economics, and linguistics, which have their root in “life, labour, and language.”

fields.title: The Adversary: A True Story of Monstrous Deception
fields.author: Emmanuel Carrère
fields.book_description: The Adversary is a French non-fiction book by Emmanuel Carrère first published in France as L'Adversaire in 2000 by Folio. The book was published in English in 2001 under the title The Adversary: A True Story of Monstrous Deception.

fields.title: The Second Sex
fields.author: Simone de Beauvoir
fields.book_description: The Second Sex is a 1949 book by the French existentialist Simone de Beauvoir, in which the author discusses the treatment of women throughout history. Beauvoir researched and wrote the book in about 14 months between 1946 and 1949. She published it in two volumes, Facts and Myths and Lived Experience.

fields.title: Existentialism Is a Humanism
fields.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
fields.book_description: Existentialism Is a Humanism is a 1946 work by the philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre, based on a lecture by the same name he gave at Club Maintenant in Paris, on 29 October 1945.

fields.title: A Winter's Promise
fields.author: Christelle Dabos
fields.book_description: The first instalment and English-language debut of the bestselling French fantasy series The Mirror Visitor. The novels have earned a huge following in France: book three debuted at #1 and spent 13 weeks on the French bestseller list. ong ago, following a cataclysm called ‘the Rupture’, the world was shattered into many floating celestial islands, named the Arks. The inhabitants of these arks each possess a unique power

fields.title: La Zone du dehors
fields.author: Alain Damasio
fields.book_description: La Zone du Dehors est un roman de science-fiction écrit par l'écrivain français Alain Damasio, publié en deux tomes.

fields.title: Le Dernier Homme
fields.author: Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville
fields.book_description: Le Dernier Homme is a French science fantasy novel in the form of a prose poem. Written by Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville and published in 1805, it was the first story of modern speculative fiction to depict the end of the world.

fields.title: Murder on the Orient Express
fields.author: Agatha Christie
fields.book_description: Murder on the Orient Express is a detective novel by English writer Agatha Christie featuring the Belgian detective Hercule Poirot. It was first published in the United Kingdom by the Collins Crime Club on 1 January 1934.

fields.title: Death on the Nile
fields.author: Agatha Christie
fields.book_description: Detective Hercule Poirot investigates the murder of a young heiress aboard a cruise ship on the Nile River.

fields.title: The Secret Adversary
fields.author: Agatha Christie
fields.book_description: The Secret Adversary is the second published detective fiction novel by British writer Agatha Christie, first published in January 1922 in the United Kingdom by The Bodley Head and in the United States by Dodd, Mead and Company later in that same year.

fields.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
fields.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
fields.book_description: The Hound of the Baskervilles is the third of the four crime novels written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle featuring the detective Sherlock Holmes.

fields.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
fields.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
fields.book_description: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes is a collection of twelve short stories by Arthur Conan Doyle, first published on 14 October 1892.

fields.title: It
fields.author: Stephen King
fields.book_description: It is a 1986 horror novel by American author Stephen King. It was his 22nd book, and his 17th novel written under his own name. The story follows the experiences of seven children as they are terrorized by an evil entity that exploits the fears of its victims to disguise itself while hunting its prey.

fields.title: It
fields.author: Stephen King
fields.book_description: It is a 1986 horror novel by American author Stephen King. It was his 22nd book, and his 17th novel written under his own name. The story follows the experiences of seven children as they are terrorized by an evil entity that exploits the fears of its victims to disguise itself while hunting its prey.

fields.title: Down Under
fields.author: Bill Bryson
fields.book_description: Down Under is the British title of a 2000 travelogue book about Australia written by best-selling travel writer Bill Bryson. In the United States and Canada it was published titled In a Sunburned Country, a title taken from the famous Australian poem

fields.title: Neither Here nor There: Travels in Europe
fields.author: Bill Bryson
fields.book_description: Neither Here nor There: Travels in Europe is a 1991 humorous travelogue by American writer Bill Bryson. It documents the author's tour of Europe in 1990, with many flashbacks to two summer tours he made in 1972 and 1973 in his college days.

fields.title: At Home: A Short History of Private Life
fields.author: Bill Bryson
fields.book_description: At Home: A Short History of Private Life is a history of domestic life written by Bill Bryson. It was published in May 2010.

fields.title: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
fields.author: Maya Angelou
fields.book_description: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings is a 1969 autobiography describing the early years of American writer and poet Maya Angelou. The first in a seven-volume series, it is a coming-of-age story that illustrates how strength of character and a love of literature can help overcome racism and trauma.

fields.title: Into the Wild
fields.author: Jon Krakauer
fields.book_description: Into the Wild is a 1996 non-fiction book written by Jon Krakauer. It is an expansion of a 9,000-word article by Krakauer on Chris McCandless titled 'Death of an Innocent', which appeared in the January 1993 issue of Outside.

fields.title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
fields.author: Dale Carnegie
fields.book_description: How to Win Friends and Influence People is a self-help book written by Dale Carnegie, published in 1936. Over 30 million copies have been sold worldwide, making it one of the best-selling books of all time. In 2011, it was number 19 on Time Magazine's list of the 100 most influential books.

fields.title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
fields.author: J. K. Rowling
fields.book_description: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is a fantasy novel written by British author J. K. Rowling.

fields.title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
fields.author: J. R. R. Tolkien
fields.book_description: The Lord of the Rings is an epic high fantasy novel by the English author and scholar J. R. R. Tolkien. Set in Middle-earth, the world at some distant time in the past, the story began as a sequel to Tolkien's 1937 children's book The Hobbit, but eventually developed into a much larger work.
